message_1:
A supermarket wants to analyze the shopping behavior of its customers. The supermarket collected the following data which represents the total amount spent in USD by each customer during their last five visits:

Customer A: [80, 90, 85, 70, 75]
Customer B: [40, 60, 50, 55, 45]
Customer C: [200, 180, 190, 195, 205]
Customer D: [120, 100, 110, 105, 115]

Use cluster analysis to group these customers based on their shopping behavior. Determine the number of clusters, their means, and the members of each cluster.
message_2:
To perform cluster analysis, we will first calculate the mean spending of each customer:

Customer A: (80 + 90 + 85 + 70 + 75) / 5 = 80
Customer B: (40 + 60 + 50 + 55 + 45) / 5 = 50
Customer C: (200 + 180 + 190 + 195 + 205) / 5 = 194
Customer D: (120 + 100 + 110 + 105 + 115) / 5 = 110

Now, we will use the k-means clustering algorithm to group the customers. We will start by assuming two clusters and calculate the initial centroids:

Cluster 1: (80 + 50) / 2 = 65
Cluster 2: (194 + 110) / 2 = 152

Next, we will assign each customer to the nearest centroid:

Customer A (80): Cluster 1 (65)
Customer B (50): Cluster 1 (65)
Customer C (194): Cluster 2 (152)
Customer D (110): Cluster 2 (152)

Now, we will recalculate the centroids based on the new cluster assignments:

Cluster 1: (80 + 50) / 2 = 65
Cluster 2: (194 + 110) / 2 = 152

Since the centroids did not change, the algorithm has converged, and we have our final clusters:

Cluster 1 (mean = 65): Customer A, Customer B
Cluster 2 (mean = 152): Customer C, Customer D

Based on this cluster analysis, we have two groups of customers. The first group consists of Customer A and Customer B, who spend an average of 65 USD per visit. The second group consists of Customer C and Customer D, who spend an average of 152 USD per visit.
